plysurfacehandler¶

class plysurfacehandler.plysurfacehandler(vertexlist: Optional[Iterator[plysurfacehandler.dataclass.vertex]] = None, facelist: Optional[Iterator[plysurfacehandler.dataclass.face]] = None, surfacelist: Optional[Iterator[plysurfacehandler.dataclass.surface]] = None)¶

Container for data of data for ply-file. The data is divided in 2 parts. First in the file 1 connected 3d-object is saved. The object is described via :

  • vertices with their 3d-position,

  • edges with the 2 indices of the corresponding vertices

  • and faces with a list of indices of corresponding edges

The second part is the description of surfaces of the object. These surfaces are described minimal via 4 borders, which are a list of connected edges. These four border are the 4 cardinal direction up, right, down and left.

Additional every surface can have a map which translates every 3d-point on the surface to a 2d-map

complete_surfaces_with_map()¶

Create for every Surface a 2d-map. This map has for every point on the surface a corresponding 2d-point. See create_surfacemap for more information

Raises

{NoSurfaceForMap}, {IndexError}

create_surfacemap(index)¶

Create for the Surface with index a 2d-map. This map has for every point on the surface a corresponding 2d-point.

Raises

{NoSurfaceForMap}, {IndexError}

get_vertexpositions() → Iterator[Iterator[float]]¶

Returns the vertices as positiontuples, eg: [(0,1,2),(3,4,5)] automaticly recognizes how many coordinates there are (1,2 or 3) in case of only one coordinate available list contains instead of tuples the coordinates directly, eg: [0,3]

Returns

A list of the position of each point

Return type

Iterator[ Tuple[float, float, float] ]

get_faceindices() → Iterator[Iterator[int]]¶

Every face is described by the indices of the corresponding edges

Returns

Gives back every face as tuple of edgeindices

Return type

Iterator[ Tuple[ int ]]

get_number_surfaces() → int¶
get_surface(index: int) → Iterator[plysurfacehandler.dataclass.surface]¶

Returns an object for saving all available data to surface.

Return type

surface

class plysurfacehandler.vertex(x=None, y=None, z=None)¶
is_compatible_to(other_vertex)¶
class plysurfacehandler.face(vertex_indices=None)¶
class plysurfacehandler.surface(rightup=None, leftup=None, leftdown=None, rightdown=None, surfacename=None, vertexlist: Optional[Iterator[int]] = None, faceindices: Optional[Iterator[Iterator[int]]] = None, mapping: Optional[Tuple[Tuple[Tuple[float, ...], ...], ...]] = None)¶

Container for data of surface.

Variables

  • mapping – 2dMatrix with max-3d-position

  • rightup – Index of vertice in the rightup-corner

  • rightdown – Index of vertice in the rightdown-corner

  • leftup – Index of vertice in the leftup-corner

  • leftdown – Index of vertice in the leftdown-corner

get_surfacemap()¶

Get a surfacemap to the mapping.

Return type

surfacemap_utils.surfacemap

get_datamatrix_of_surfacematrix()¶
Returns

surface data of gridpositions

Return type

Tuple[ Tuple[ Position ],… ]

get_borders()¶

Returns the border of the surface.

Returns

all subborders as indexlist of vertices. The returned borders are in this order: up, left, down, right. The order of the vertices in the borders:

  • up: uppright - upleft

  • left: upleft - downleft

  • down: downleft - downright

  • right: downright - upright

Return type

Tuple[ Tuple[int,…], Tuple[int,…], Tuple[int,…],Tuple[int,…]]

add_surfacemap(surfacemap: plysurfacehandler.surfacemap_utils.surfacemap_class.surfacemap)¶

Should only be called by plysurfacecontainer.
